block.p: Washington ignored many warnings that its arms sales to Iran were based on faulty intelligence and were unlikely to reach their goals, a staff report prepared for the Senate Intelligence Committee says.

A Lebanese man may be extradited to the United States after the Justice Department said it would not seek the death penalty for his role in a 1985 hijacking of an American jet where a U.S. Navy diver was killed.
China's intellectuals were warned, in a long report in the country's major newspapers, that the recent atmosphere of freer expression and discussion would be sharply curtailed.

Chinese in the U.S. condemned the dismissal of the Secretary General of the Communist Party in a statement reportedly signed by at least 400 Chinese college students that suggests they might not return to China if hard-line policies prevail.
Misleading U.S. data cost Iraq a major Iraqi defeat last year in the war with Iran, a top Iraqi official said, adding that the United States was trying to prolong the war to increase its influence.

Britain's 'north-south division' is a matter of debate, stoked by Labor Party politicians in what is expected to be a national election this year. The Prime Minister, however, has tried to discount the split.
Corazon C. Aquino flew to Cotabato, which for the past week has been the center of the heaviest Moslem fighting in the Philippines in years. The President traveled under heavy military protection.

A Nicaraguan Cardinal was abused verbally, beaten and robbed in Miami, said relatives and friends who believed the incident was political in nature. The Primate is a critic of the Sandinista Government.

A rebel general in Ecuador is hiding after his release from prison was gained by commandos who took the country's President hostage. Family members said the general feared arrest or ''physical harm.''

A push to ban cigarette advertising is planned in Congress this year, fueled by a Supreme Court decision that suggests the Government could impose a ban and by the finding that cigarettes harm nonsmokers.

Asian students face more racial bias when they apply to the nation's most selective universities, Asian-American leaders contend. They say schools are reacting after years of admitting greater proportions of Asian-Americans.

A $6 billion atom smasher project is being considered by President Reagan, who may express support for the project, a subatomic particle accelerator about 50 miles in circumference, in his State of the Union Message, officials said.
Alcohol and drugs and rail accidents have been linked in many of the major crashes in recent years, government and industry officials say. But over all, rail safety has improved.
Desegregation of Forsyth County, Ga., is the aim of a campaign planned by civil rights leaders after violence erupted Saturday between a ''brotherhood march'' and the Ku Klux Klan.

The Southwest is digging out from the snow in the aftermath of a record-setting storm that closed highways, shut airports and caused the Governor of New Mexico to declare four counties disaster areas.

Seattle's second bishop is asserting his authority more publicly, a year after he was sent by the Vatican to support orthodox positions. Bishop Donald Wuerl was given some of the power held by the more liberal Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen.
A New Orleans tax rise was defeated. The increase was proposed to finance more police and fire protection but, despite pervasive fears about crime, voters rejected the plan overwhelmingly.

The McMartin sex abuse case will take an unusual turn tomorrow when a former prosecutor who sold the inside story of his role in the case to Hollywood testifies about possible suppression of evidence.

News analysis: Mark S. Fowler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission who has announced that he will resign in the spring, treated television as commerce and sought to demystify broadcasting.

More U.S. orchestras are in trouble than at any time since the Depression, afflicted with strikes and lockouts, struggling to raise money and in some cases canceling seasons and even declaring bankruptcy.
Politics: Buchanan's dilemma Liberals peek out and see spring Regional
L.I.R.R. workers walked off the job, shutting down the nation's busiest commuter line. The leader of the engineers' union said he had reached an ''irreconcilable impasse'' with the line.

Commuters put together car pools, made hotel reservations, and imposed on friends and relatives with apartments in the city as they planned how to get to work now that the Long Island Rail Road is on strike.

A man was convicted of murder in the death of a New Jersey state trooper in 1981, but the jury, after deliberating for five days, was unable to reach a verdict on his co-defendant who the state said had actually killed the trooper.

News analysis: Mario Cuomo has won a political victory, many say, by naming a special prosecutor to investigate a racially motivated attack in Howard Beach at a key time, as he is considering seeking the Democratic nomination for President.
Ending leases in rent-stablized units will be advocated in a State housing study, according to officials familiar with the document which is to be released this week by the Cuomo Administration.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was recalled in weekend religious services keyed to the national holiday honoring the slain civil rights leader.
